column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1571234/reviews?ref_=tt_sa_3;bob-the-movie-man;At last
column2: the hilarious Brexit comedy we've all been waiting for.;5/10;"As comedy goes it's classic gold! London has been transferred
column3: presumably via a futuristic huge forklift truck of some kind
column4: onto a huge chassis and is now chugging its way across mainland Europe. Needing fuel
column5: it has the capability to gobble-up (take that Barnier!) other towns and cities (also roaming the countryside) which London 'digests' (smoke that Tusk!). Curiously
column6: the captured cities' inhabitants are not exterminated but integrated into the City's population: so much for any anti-immigration policy! (LOL).But all doesn't go entirely smoothly for the UK capital. The Lord Mayor of London (Patrick Malahide) declares ""We should never have gone into Europe. It's the biggest mistake we ever made"". (Classic: how we SNORTED with laughter!)Stuffing it squarely to the 'remainers'
column7: London makes its own future. ""It's time to show the world how strong London can be"". Having conquered most of Europe
column8: it's time to set its sights on new markets to conquer: so London takes the Chinese on! (Now the tears of laughter are flowing freely!) Trade deals have never been more entertaining since ""Star Wars: The Phantom Menace""!OK
column9: so in the interests of 'advertising standards'
column10: I'd better make clear before you rush out to the cinema expecting a comedy feature that my tongue is firmly in my cheek here. For ""Mortal Engines"" is the latest sci-fi feature from Peter Jackson. But when viewed from a Brexit perspective
column11: it's hilarious!In terms of plot
column12: this (like ""Waterworld"") makes clever use of the Universal logo to set the agenda. The world has been decimated with a worldwide war - though clearly one that selectively destroyed bits of London and not others! - and the survivors must try to survive in any way they can. Settlements are divided between those that are 'static' and those (like London) that are mobile and constantly evolving: ""Municipal Darwinism"" as it is hysterically described. But London
column13: or rather the power-crazed Londoner Thaddeus Valentine (Hugo Weaving)
column14: wants revolution rather than evolution and he is working on development of one of the super-weapons that started the world's demise in the first place.But Hester Shaw (Hera Hilmar)
column15: separated when young from her mother Pandora (yes
column16: she has a box and we've seen it: wink
column17: wink) is intent on stopping him
column18: since she is on a personal path of vengence. Teaming up with Londoner Tom (Robert Sheehan) and activist Anna Fang (Jihae) they must face both Thaddeus and the ever-relentless Shrike (Stephen Lang) to try to derail the destructive plan.Anna Fang declares ""I'm not subtle"" and neither is this movie. The film is loud and action-filled and (as a significant plus) visually extremely impressive with it. I'm not a great fan of excessive CGI but here it is essential
column19: and the special-effects team do a great job. The production design is tremendous - a lot of money has been thrown at this - and the costume design inventive
column20: a high-spot (again snortworthy) being the Beefeater guards costumes!Where the film really crashes
column22: is with the dialogue. The screenplay by Jackson himself
column23: with his regular writers Fran Walsh and Phillipa Boyens contains some absolute clunkers
column24: notwithstanding the unintended LOL-worthy Brexit irony. It's jaw-droppingly bad
column26: the only real ""name"" in the whole film is Jackson-favourite Hugo Weaving. Just about everyone else in the cast is pretty well unknown
column27: and in many cases it shows. Standing head and shoulders though for me over the rest of the cast was Icelandic actress Hera Hilmar
column28: who strikes a splendidly feisty pose as the mentally and physically scarred Hester. I look forward to seeing what she does next.Story-wise
column29: there's not a sci-fi film that's not been looted
column30: and a number of other films seem to be plundered too. (I can't comment on how much of this comes from the source book by Philip Reeve). The Londonmobile looks for all the world like Monty Python's ""Crimson Permanent Assurance Company""; the teenage female lead is Sarah Connors
column31: relentlessly pursued by The Terminator; the male lead is archaologist cum hot-shot pilot Indiana Solo
column32: leather jacket and all; there is a Blade Runner moment; a battle that is a meld of ""The Great Wall"" and Morannon from ""The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers""; a less sophisticated aerial location from ""The Empire Strikes Back""; and another classic Star Wars moment (without the words being actually said!).Now I'm loathe to say anything bad about director Peter Jackson
column33: after his breathtakingly memorable ""They Shall Not Grown Old"". And the film has its moments of flair
column34: most memorably a ""life flashing before your eyes scene"" that I found genuinely moving. But overall
column36: it's a bit of a mess. It's a long way from being the worse film I've seen this year by a long stroke - it kept me interested and amused in equal measure for the running time. But I think given it's initially bombed at the Box Office
column37: any plans Jackson had to deliver a series of these movies might need to be self-funded.(For the full graphical review
column38: please check out One Mann's Movies on the web or Facebook. Thanks).";23 December 2018

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1571234/reviews?ref_=tt_sa_3;haydenagain;Not the perfect beginning for the Mortal Engines Quartet like I expected.;6/10;"The clash of urban titans has arrived to the big screen in this latest review for Mortal Engines. Does this movie live up to the book and the lore? Well let's get started.Plot:In a Dystopian future world ruined by an ancient apocalypse
column2: gigantic Mobile Cities now dominant the landscape. Battling each other for survival and remaining resources. While those that choose to avoid it live behind a gigantic wall in eastern Asia called Shan Guao. Drawn together by an unexpected turn of Events
column3: Hester Shaw and Tom Natsworthy are cast out of the Traction City of London into the wastes of the Great Hunting ground. Now must rely on each other to survive. As they find their way back to London
column4: a cybernetic Bounty Hunter begins a relentless manhunt upon them.Likes:Mortal Engines is an epic
column5: innovative and visual fuelled sci-fi adventure never before realised in filmmaking. The designs of the moving cities are really captivating and thoroughly detailed. Especially how London has a lot of striking resemblances to its real-world counterpart.

column1: The special effects and the environment overall are stunning and breath-taking. And the action is thrilling
column2: suspenseful and high-octane from start to finish. I also love how accurately London devours cities
column3: just like how I imagined it in the first chapter. And the film is actually a lot faithful to the novel in terms of characters and setting unlike most other books to film.

column1: The casting choices for the movie are pretty solid such as Hera Hilmar as Hester Shaw
column2: Robert Sheehan as Tom Natsworthy
column3: Hugo Weaving as Valentine and Stephen Lang as the Cyborg Shrike. Who (except for Valentine
column4: see the dislikes below) do stay true to their characters from the novels. Stephen Lang's portrayal of the Cyborg bounty hunter Shrike is probably my biggest highlight. He gives Shrike plenty of good vibe and a sense of humanity and character when most of the others can't really grasp that interest.

column1: But really that's all the good I have to say this film has on a visual aspect. But the Dislikes? Well... they do outweigh the needs of the few.Dislikes:So like I said I have read the book before seeing this movie recently and firstly
column2: it doesn't truly follow the full length of it. The first half is mostly accurate to the book but after the main leads get captured by a slave town and being saved by Anna Fang that's where the story starts getting condensed for time.

column1: From there
column2: it tries to attempt to recreate popular themes and moments that relate too heavily upon Star Wars or Mad Max content. For example the Anti-Traction Leagues final assault on London (Not in the Book) which has a large resemblance to certain scenes in A New Hope and Return of the Jedi. So not an original movie as one was to expect.The book followed three leads. Tom
column3: Hester and Katherine Valentine. Both of them had an equal view of the events that transpire in the novel. But the movie is too concerned about a budget and a long running time to fully adapt everything that it removes the important aspects of the characters and climatic moments witnessed:1.) Katherine doesn't die in the end. Her pet husky
column4: Dog is missing also.2.) London itself doesn't get destroyed by Medusa.3.) Tom and Hester's romance is rarely ever seen and aren't captured by another Town called Tunbridge.4.) Medusa is used first on the Shield Wall and not first used on a German city called Panzerstadt like in the Novel.5.) How Mobile Cities conserve resources for fuel without consuming them too quickly is also left unexplained.

column1: And those were moments that fans of the book remember so well but Christian Rivers and Peter Jackson had missed and that's really shallow. If the movie was 40 minutes longer
column2: then maybe it could have adapted the full story.

column1: A few of the characters from the book are not properly portrayed as I hoped. Mainly with Anna Fang
column2: Valentine and Hester herself. Anna Fang appears to be edgier and distasteful of people from Traction cities than her calm and nicer counterpart. Her personality and lines are a bit mechanical to get any connection to her or her motivations as an Anti-Tractionist.

column1: Thaddeus Valentine is THE main villain instead of Magnus Chrome who both show a sudden switch in personalities where the Mayor despises the use of Medusa and not the latter. And he is much more of a fanatic and a power-hungry dictator and even does cynical Out-of-Character moves like try to bash all of London and its people to their death just to kill A FREAKING WALL? By the way
column2: his plan is stupid. All he boasts about is destroying the Shield Wall and killing Anti-Tractionists. But what's the reason bro? In the movie
column3: London isn't dying like in the book
column4: and seems to run on enough power and resources to keep going on without quarrelling with other cities. So why kill a bunch of normal innocent people anyway regardless? It just feels far too personal to understand. So to put it mildly
column5: his character is too underdeveloped and ludicrously insane to be taken seriously as the villain. But at least Hugo Weaving did well with the material he had to work with anyway.

column1: I wouldn't say Hester Shaw's personality is not much like her counterpart in literature. But it's that small scar on the left side of her jaw that's the problem here. In the books she is described as being a battered sixteen year old girl with a long scar that appears over her left eye
column2: nose and right chin. That is disappointing even from a Hollywood point of view because she could have had that scar easy without having to worry about ruining the actresses' beauty. Or you could just have it cutting over her left side of the face instead no problem. But Jackson
column3: the scar is not strong with this one!

column1: So I hope that wasted too much book to film criticism I included.Verdict?
When push comes to shove
column2: Mortal Engines delivers an all new visual
column3: steam-punked action adventure of survival that does do well to keep faith to its source material. But like most other book-to-film adaptations
column4: it removes too much flow from the story and pacing of the book in order to be congested for time just to strive to compete with the bigger leagues of today's filmmaking world. If Peter Jackson himself was in the director's chair
column5: maybe he could have been able to do better at adapting the movie. But I don't think it would have made much of a difference regardless. In the meantime
column6: it looks like fans may have to wait a little while longer until The Mortal Engines Quartet gets a proper adaption. Hopefully with better results.

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;psifi872;Unfaithful;1/10;"The main problem with the movie is it so very unfaithful to the book. It doesn't even attempt to remain true to what the book is truly about.First of all

column8: ""darkness
column9: and the ""universe
column10: with some daytime pop psychology mixed in. For an example
column11: the movie has Mrs. Which
column12: played by Oprah Winfrey
column13: say ""The only thing faster than the speed of light is the speed of darkness."" What rubbish! I genuinely hate that line. Theologically
column14: even just morally
column15: it's garbage. Light doesn't have to outrun the dark. Good is not weaker than evil. The smallest speck of light is enough to brighten the most encompassing darkness. That's the message we should be sending children
column16: not some banal quip that makes evil seem stronger than it really is. The movie's fatal flaw is shown mainly in the characters
column17: but also a bit in how the plot was handled. I'll start with the characters

column23: Murray is a renowned and VERY well-respected scientist
column24: not some outsider on the fringes of his field. This is a man who is consulted by the President
column25: at times! His work with the tesseract was a group effort with other scientists
column26: not just his wife. The movie utterly trashed his motives for developing the tesseract. He didn't want to ""shake hands with the universe
column27: whatever that means. Murray in the book was a man of faith
column28: working for the good of his fellow men. The tesseract was supposed to help people
column29: not just fulfill some personal agenda. Murray in the book took risks
column31: but as part of his responsibilities to his team and country. Equally flawed was the movie's version of Mrs. Whatsit. In the book
column35: who used to be a star
column36: before sacrificing herself in a battle against evil...a battle she won. She was a fun character
column38: playing a game at being human. She dressed as an old tramp and stole sheets. The sheets in the book
column40: weren't stolen to create some magnificent robe for her to look beautiful in
column41: for her vanity. Nope. In the book
column42: she took the sheets to make cheesy ghosts
column43: in order to scare people away from the haunted house. The worst thing about the movie Mrs. Whatsit was how she treated Meg. Consistently and frequently through the movie
column44: Mrs. Whatsit bullied and belittled Meg
column45: showing intense dislike and openly wishing she wasn't there. What an incredibly terrible message to send! This is supposed to be a wise leader
column48: but that's how she treats a child? Compare that to the book
column49: where Mrs. Whatsit is playful and gentle

column58: and instead showing them scenes of pain
column59: as it was in the book. I don't know why they got rid of this bit of character development in favor of CGI crap about balancing on rocks. It's just one time of many
column60: where something deep was replaced with something shallow. Zach Galifianakis could play the Man with Red Eyes
column61: if he can pull off legal evil
column63: with a deep sense of menace
column64: highlighted by a fake cheerfulness. Finally

column74: when someone is being mean to his sister. Charles Wallace barely talks in front of other people at all! There should be something otherworldly about the boy. Instead
column75: McCabe was directed to play him as a bit wild and mouthy and Charles Wallace's wisdom
column77: and intelligence were barely shown at all. Not only is this a sad waste of his character

column88: they also left out Sandy and Denys

column90: I think a single example will highlight how wrong the movie went. In the book
column91: the children arrive on Camazotz. They walk through a suburban neighborhood and see children ""playing."" The boys are bouncing balls and girls and skipping rope
column92: all simultaneously to a certain ""rhythm."" Yes
column93: the movie almost gets that much right. The children see that one child alone is out of rhythm
column94: dropping his ball and unable to keep in sync. When the mother's call the children in
column95: the errant child leaves his ball behind. They try to return the ball and the mother is terrified. She assures Meg and the others that there haven't been any ""incidents
column96: in a long time. The reader sees that although everything looks neat and tidy
column97: no one is really happy. Submission to evil brings terror and pain
column99: potentially moving scene is reduced to make room for a shallow
column100: unnecessary scene where a CGI forest attacks the kids. Speaking of out of character
column101: the entire planet of Camazotz is exactly that. There would not a beach scene like that on Camazotz. Camazotz is legal evil
column102: all the way. The evil of Camazotz does not play those sorts of mind games. It doesn't so much try and confuse you
column103: as try to get you to confuse yourself. In the movie
column104: the children are given a meal

column106: but the Man can create the illusion of a turkey dinner. Charles Wallace
column109: and knows the meal is shapeless and tasteless
column110: like sand. They weren't actually given sand to eat. The meal did what a meal should do
column111: at least on the surface. It provided nutrition

column113: with everything better about it drained away. For me

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;purrpull-24725;I Was Angry by the End of the Movie;2/10;"This was a beloved book of mine growing up. I very much related to Meg as an awkward pre-teen. I was excited about the change in the diversity of the characters and the fantastical costuming. Those were the only things that I think were done well. I purposefully did not read the book recently so I wouldn't criticize changes. However
column2: I felt some of the key elements of the story were lost. Some of the changes didn't make sense to me were they trying to make this story more exciting than it was in the book?First off
column3: the bond between Charles Wallace and Meg was totally lost in this movie. I kept waiting for it during the warming the milk scene and it never materialized. Then the whole thing about the forests popping up
column4: the whirlwind and the wall in Kamozots was entirely fabricated. Why? Then the kids that were playing ball
column5: there was a kid that was doing the ball thing erratically. They later see him being ""rehabilitated"". This whole thing was left out. And it was important because Meg had a speech at the end that talked about the difference between being the same and being equal that was very powerful. This was left out. Then the dad left which made him look like an ass
column6: but that didn't happen in the book. Yes
column7: it was Megs love that saved Charles Wallace
column8: but how they got there was wrong. I was also disappointed that they left out the humor of the happy medium
column9: who was really happy. All in all
column10: I think they missed some of the key messages that then get built upon in later books.";15 March 2018

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;NoloContendere;An example of a story co-opted for political purposes;1/10;"Ava DuVernay is best known for her directing of ""Selma""
column2: an excellent film about the civil rights struggle in Jim Crow-era Alabama. With AWIT
column3: DuVernay appears to have tried to continue her personal civil rights march by way of creating a children's film that is chock-full of good messages for young girls
column4: especially minority young girls.That's an honorable intention
column5: but it's unfortunate that she decided to advance her agenda using the name of a well-known
column6: well-loved children's book. Because that's what this is: DuVernay changed Madeleine L'Engle's story in severe ways to promote her own message instead of Ms. L'Engle's. DuVernay made the focal point of the story a young black girl's life struggles
column7: which was not the point of the original novel. That would be fine if she had created something new and original
column8: but a lot of people who grew up loving the original book were rightly disappointed or offended by the changed focus. The film also has a misanthropist (anti-male) slant that was off-putting to my family; none of the male characters are remotely competent
column9: and nearly all of them betray the main character at some point (Murray disappears for four years
column10: Calvin eats the beach food
column11: Charles Wallace becomes the bad guy) or are simply evil in their own right (the It is... itself
column12: Michael Pena kidnaps Charles Wallace
column13: Calvin's dad is verbally abusive to him). Even male characters who are minor players are portrayed as helpless or ineffective (Zach Galifianakis's clueless guru
column14: Principal Jenkins). The movie's heroes are all women
column15: period
column16: and that cannot be by accident. Just as telling is towards the end of the film when Ms. Who is naming off legendary heroes
column17: all except one were non-white. Again
column19: and is just as wrong as it would have been if all the heroes she had named were white.There are plenty of other posts about the poor acting
column22: and overuse of facial close-up shots (DuVernay uses close-ups with the same proliferation that J.J. Abrams uses lens flare)
column23: so I won't go into those here. Suffice it to say
column24: this movie is AWIT in name only";10 April 2018

column2: including all three of the ""Mrs."" were visually different than the original book. But it worked. They were wild
column3: weird and wonderful.Until we get to Camazotz. In the original book
column4: Camazotz was
column5: in gamer terms
column6: lawful evil. Perfectly controlled
column7: with all individuality wiped out. These were regular people
column8: like us
column9: except that a child who drops a ball is an ""Aberration"" and must be ""Reprocessed"" so that he will never again desire to ""deviate"". IT claimed that it had achieved peace by eliminating all differences.In the movie
column10: Camazotz was chaotic evil. Deserts randomly turned into tornadoes randomly turned into housing developments randomly turned into crowded beaches. It wasn't clear that any of the people were anything but an illusion. The only bit that was done right was the perfect neighborhood with the bouncing balls. Actors were of different skin tones
column11: but were otherwise identical in facial expression
column12: dress
column13: etc. Creepy and very much true to the source material. But then it just folded away like it was all an illusion. Which completely undid the point.In the book
column14: IT forced mindless compliance and called it peace. Meg saved her little brother through the one thing IT couldn't understand (or control): love.

column1: Given the number of people (across the political spectrum) who are trying to force orderly compliance
column2: I was really hoping that the movie would do justice to these themes. Instead
column3: it ran more with a trite ""love yourself
column4: love conquers all"" kind of message. Trite and nearly meaningless.The screenwriters evidently missed the point of the book. Too bad. It is an excellent book.";9 March 2018

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;bakmasha;A Wrinkle in Time? More Like A Waste Of Time!;1/10;"Going into the theater I was with my seventh grade sister and my boyfriend. We were just finding a way to pass the time by going to the movies and to just hang out because what else do you really do on a Sunday night in the winter. I'm not very critical of movies or actors
column2: I like most films I see even if they are a bit cheesy/cringe worthy and I never really knew what ""bad acting"" looked like
column3: so walking into this I was expecting a mediocre film. I heard good things about the book that was published in 1962
column4: lots of people said it was a classic that everyone adored. The casting also raised the stakes a bit considering Oprah Winfrey
column5: Reese Witherspoon
column6: Mindy Kaling and
column7: one of my favorite actors
column8: Zach Galifianakis were in it. They were also the face of all of the commercials shown for this science fiction film. The first fifteen minutes I was thinking to myself
column9: ""This isn't very good so far
column10: but I'm going to give it some time
column11: I'm sure it will get better!"" Boy was I wrong. The acting and plot may have been some of the worst I have ever seen. Let me take this apart step by step.

column1: Let's start with the plot. I haven't read the book
column2: but I read a brief synopsis before we went in so that I could have a better understanding. To summarize it
column3: the main character Meg (Storm Reid) and her younger brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) have been left alone with their mother after their scientist father has disappeared for five years. Their father had thought up of a concept called a tesseract. A tesseract is the fifth dimension that can shorten the distances across both time and space therefore
column4: forming a ""wrinkle in time""
column5: hence the name of the movie. The kids
column6: especially Meg
column7: have been dealing with the absence of their father very poorly
column8: affecting their social life and school work. Out of nowhere
column9: (literally with no reason) Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) shows up and starts talking nonsense about their father and his study. After this incident
column10: the kids get involved with two other mysterious astral travelers (Oprah Winfrey and Mindy Kaling). Now this is where it gets messy; the director did a bad job explaining on what was happening and why. One minute the kids and the travelers would be on another planet
column11: and the next they would encounter an ""evil force"". To sum it up
column12: the whole movie was these kids looking for their father with these mysterious travelers and !!SPOILER ALERT!! They find him and they all live happily ever after. The transitions between each part of the movie was unclear and confusing. The director did NOT do a good job.

column1: Now
column2: I don't know much about acting and I haven't really noticed bad acting before but this movie was the definition of bad acting. The main character
column3: Meg
column4: was honestly terrible. I just remember this one line that she said and it made me cringe so much. Reese Witherspoon
column5: Oprah Winfrey and Mindy Kaling weren't bad at acting but it just seemed like they didn't fit in with this type of movie. I view them as serious actors but this movie is like a joke in my eyes. The script was just not good
column6: at all. The actors would say obvious things that just made you go ""Really? Are you really that dumb?"" I do give the movie some credit for having good actors to star in it to attract attention but that does not mean it was a good movie.

column1: The one good thing that I will say about this awful movie is that the special effects were pretty cool. It was interesting and was probably the only thing that kept my attention throughout the movie. The whole concept of this movie was good and it has potential
column2: but the way it was approached was just really terrible. I think after all the reviews this movie has gotten
column3: the producers would do many things differently. So
column4: to sum everything up
column5: this is my least favorite movie I have ever seen and I was VERY disappointed. Definitely a WASTE of time. The only reason why I would tell someone to watch this film is for me to discuss the things that were so bad about it with that person. I wish I could wrinkle that time when I was in the theater.";1 June 2018

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;micomariorivera;YouHateGoodMovies;3/10;Disney Studios doesn't have a great track record with live action features in the last decade. column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;madpigmadpig;Extremely disappointing considering what they could have done with the story;3/10;"I saw A Wrinkle in Time today. The first half hour or so had potential
column2: as the little brother was set up as an articulate champion of justice type who dressed down two teachers for spreading malicious gossip about him and his family
column3: and then supported his sister. All this while apparently marshaling the powers that be of the universe to help find their missing father. The sister started out with some potential too
column4: beating up a particularly vicious bully and walking out on a principal who was trying to tear her down without getting the whole story behind her actions first. The acting and makeup for the 3 universe goddess ladies was rather off-putting and honestly came off as TV movie quality
column5: but the CGI once they crossed over to a new place was impressive. Unfortunately
column6: the whole movie falls flat on its face immediately after that and never recovers. Leaving the heavy-handed and insufficiently heartfelt scene with the seer out
column7: the little brother disappears briefly without explanation (only to reappear later also without explanation) during which time the kids run through a supernatural natural disaster of sorts and escape in a barely believable (even in the context of fantasy) way. Shortly after the little brother reappears
column8: he touches the hand of one baddie and suddenly turns into a power-mad villain
column9: which makes no sense since he showed no signs of avarice up to that point and not a drop of darkness in his personality to be used in turning him. If anything
column10: the setup made him seem more likely to end up the hero of the story. This is just clumsy writing. When they finally find the father
column11: despite the fact he's been trapped in the core of evil for the whole universe for 4 years
column12: he shows no signs of having changed in any way - plus he was way too easy to find but that's another issue. Then
column13: even though he's supposed to have been trapped there
column14: he just decides to teleport him and his daughter back home at will. What!?! Couldn't he have done that
column15: say 4 years earlier if it was that simple!?! Also
column16: when he teleports away and the daughter wills herself to stay to go after her brother
column17: the boyfriend is nowhere near and in the end the daughter and her brother go home without the boyfriend... and yet he's there when they arrive home... with no explanation whatsoever. Oh
column18: and one more plot hole regarding the boyfriend. The little brother asked him to come along because they needed his sense of diplomacy
column19: but he never used it once. He barely even spoke. Both he and the little brother had considerable potential as characters
column20: but were not really used at all. What a waste. Finally
column21: the climax ""battle"" scene of the film kind of undermined the moral of the story (that you should like yourself the way you are) since the argument the daughter made to un-evil her brother was that they loved each other and therefore he couldn't be evil. Huh?Oh
column22: one last note. There was one little moment when the bother yelled to the sister ""Shut up
column23: Meg!"" Surely someone working on that movie must have seen the show Family Guy once in their life and realized that line would have all the wrong pop culture connotations for a moderately large portion of the audience? I mean
column25: I don't watch that show and even I know that catchphrase. There was a lot of laughter in the theater at that moment
column26: and I think that's why.I'm guessing something important in the original written story was excised from the screenplay to fill it so full of holes. If not

column28: it wants to be Neverending Story
column29: but it just isn't. At all. Not even close.";10 March 2018

column2: there's an insulting travesty such as ... well... The Hobbit. Tragically
column3: there's much more than a whiff of the latter in Disney's big-budget shot at breathing life into author Madeleine L'Engle's metaphysical whimsy. Ava DuVernay's A Wrinkle in Time is a bloated but sweet movie you desperately want to like
column4: gosh darn it. Sadly
column5: it's too unsalvageable to even defend as harmless children's entertainment - so cataclysmically off-base that
column6: rather than rescue it from Camazotz
column7: you'd probably go out of your way to maroon it there
column8: and save everyone from the heartbreak of its existence. L'Engle's novel had a gentle otherworldliness in its whimsy
column9: but the only thing 'otherworldly' in Jennifer Lee and Jeff Stockwell's screenplay is that it reads like an extraterrestrial inhabitant clumsily trying to piece together how humans verbally communicate. The film drips with more grotesquely stale exposition than dialogue
column10: with the unappetizing side order of characters reacting to the increasingly fantastic happenstances as if shot with tranquilizer darts
column11: dopily shuffling from point to point without ever seemingly registering an emotional response. Fall into an immediate conversation about feelings with a boy you've never met? Already outlandish for a teenager. Travel across the universe with a passive-aggressive space-witch who eventually takes the form of a flying cabbage? Oh. Sure. Come face-to-face with the root of all unhappiness and evil in all multiverses? Meh. It almost defies belief that the director of the flooring
column12: poignant Selma is capable of producing a film so shallow and emotionally stilted. It would normally play as charming to have a children's film bounce with the same episodic stream-of-consciousness of a child's storytelling
column13: but DuVernay is never fully able to corral the playful lilt of L'Engle's gossamer
column14: episodic plot. Instead
column15: the film lurches from blandly dazzling planet to confusedly extraneous supporting character with nauseating
column16: plodding incoherence. Loopy yogi Zach Galifianakis and charmingly threatening Michael Peña do their best to raise laughs with their awkwardly out-of-place cameos
column17: but even they fail to distract from how flat the razzle-dazzle of each new alien landscape in between feels. The film's expensive-but-unsophisticated visual effects
column20: benignly underwhelming (and what little wonder is raised by their colourful panoramas is immediately extinguished by the unwanted musical accompaniment of an asinine pop remix). Similarly
column21: the ludicrously kitschy costumes do nothing to dispel the aesthetic of tackiness (poor Oprah looks like she should be engaged in a ray gun battle with Ming the Merciless from Flash Gordon). If this is what $100 million looks like

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;kjproulx;A Mediocre Outing For Disney;5/10;Everyone seems to be throwing shade on Disney for being too attached to franchises and not doing anything original. They are definitely a studio that recycles ideas and makes them into unique new things
column2: so they are always worthy of applause
column3: no matter how familiar one of their films may seem. I was very much looking forward to A Wrinkle in Time. I had no prior knowledge of its source material
column4: so I was seeing it as an original film that was hitting theatres sometime soon. That time has now come
column5: and although I'm something who tries to see the best in every film that I watch
column6: there's no denying that this one just doesn't quite feel right. Not to say this is a bad movie by any means
column7: but here's why it fails to reach its potential on multiple occasions.After her father disappears and ends up somewhere distant in the universe
column8: his daughter Meg is sent by three women on a quest through time and space to locate him. Accompanied by her younger brother Charles Wallace and newfound friend Clavin
column9: the three of them embark on a strange journey across the universe. With unique visuals surround each and every scene and a fantastic performance by Storm Reid in the leading role
column10: the epic scale
column11: and emotional impact are truly what will win over the viewers. Aside from those elements
column12: this is a fairly sloppy movie that tries a little too hard to be unique.Without ruining the film
column13: it relies very heavily on the character of Charles Wallace to heighten certain aspects of the story. For that reason
column14: the film suffers from a few laughable lines of dialogue
column15: due to the fact that Deric McCabe may not have been the right kid to cast in this particular role. I was taken out of many dramatic moments
column16: simply because I just wasn't buying into the way he was delivering his lines.On top of that
column17: the three goddesses in Mindy Kaling
column19: and Oprah Winfrey are present for a purpose
column20: but they could've easily been excluded from the film once they bring the main characters to the places they need to be. They're quite annoying and simply unnecessary when it came to the story itself. Witherspoon was solid
column21: but that's only because she had more things to do with her role than the others.The most frustrating part about this film is that Chris Pine is great in this movie and the conclusion of the third act felt earned and I found myself emotionally invested and caring about certain characters. The reason that aspect of the film is frustrating is that the film deviates too much from his character and it just feels like it drags quite a while before reaching him. That's a huge problem
column22: especially when reflecting on the fact that the runtime is a mere 109 minutes.In the end
column23: A Wrinkle in Time may have been a much better film with a few re-writes and about 20-30 minutes added on in order to expand the world a little more. The editing felt choppy at times
column24: certain characters appear in places without explanation
column25: and the solid visuals aren't enough to elevate the sloppy plot execution. Yes
column26: there are a few great performances and the core story is worth watching
column27: but there are too many problems surrounding that element to really send anyone out to see this in theatres. This is a neat and complex idea that would've worked as a much grander and elongated epic. Ava Duvernay is a fantastic director that tried a little too hard to impress here and I truly hate to have to admit that about this promising storyline. Overall
column28: this is a pretty middle-of-the-road picture.;9 March 2018

column7: the part of the movie on Camazotz is restrained to completely boring borderline filler. Another big change is that the planet Ixchel is completely removed from the movie despite being a major part of the book without any attempt to even replace it. Even more randomly it seems they changed the introduction and conclusion specifically to highlight Calvin as a love interest. Another issue that sinks the movie: The visuals do not live up to the book's descriptions. The beautiful creature described on Uriel literally looks like flying cabbage in the movie and Camazotz looks less like the madness described in the book and more like a generic small town neighborhood. Possibly a bigger issue than terrible illustration or terrible adaptation

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;alaynad;Disappointing;3/10;"I had read the book when I was in college and had watched the 2003 movie only to be disappointed. I was so hopeful that this remake would be good since now CG is way better but I was still so disappointed. The plot drags along so slowly only to cram in Meg's confrontation of The IT as an afterthought when the writers realized that they had to wrap it up. The movie leaves out so many important parts of the book like why Charles Wallace gets taken over by The IT and the whole part with Mrs. Beast after Meg
column2: Calvin
column3: and her father first leave Camazotz without Charles Wallace. That part is a crucial part for Meg's character development! It's why she is able to go back and save her brother from The IT by using her love for her brother instead of focusing on numbers to keep The IT out of her mind. They completely skip that part about The IT having the power to reach into and control/play with their minds so much too! Ugh. The movie does nothing to explain what is actually going on with the characters and focuses so much on love and trying too hard to get the message across with special effects that it just ends up being sloppily thrown together and waters down the message. They were trying WAY too hard.

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;gerold-firl-279-327147;"Not as bad as advertised; not as good as it should";5/10;"I read this book when I was a kid and loved it. Was looking forward to seeing the adaptation.
It has some serious flaws
column2: but it's not as bad as the reviews make out. It's enjoyable and interesting to watch
column3: with largely good effects and performances by the actors. The reason I give it a lukewarm 5/10 is because of a key failure in the story.

column1: The key message of the film is taken direct from the book: the power of love and family. It's a message everyone can agree on. But the story inexplicably fails to honor the theme in ways that lost the plot for me.
One of the key instructions for the children from the Weird Sisters was to stay together. The kids are on their own in the realm of evil and it's good advice
column2: but the first thing that happens is they split up. Not only do Meg and Calvin lose young Charles Wallace
column3: they don't even seem to notice he's gone. When he suddenly reappears with no explanation they don't even seem surprised.

column1: It's a poorly constructed scene that broke the spell
column2: but it wasn't unique. The people that they love suddenly disappear and no one seems to notice. They suddenly reappear and everyone just blithely trudges onward. It really undermines the story and the message.

column1: That said
column2: there is still plenty to enjoy. Read the book to get a measure of how much better it could have been.";12 November 2020

column1: https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1620680/reviews?ref_=tt_urv;imdave-1;Don't bother.;2/10;"(Maybe spoilers
column2: but you knew how it was going to end anyway.)This movie is about a misunderstood girl
column3: who is bullied at school by some mean girls
column4: and her father who somehow goes away to somewhere and for some reason some women come from somewhere and kinda help her and her brother find him. Kinda. Actually
column5: they don't really help much at all. And for some reason they're joined by a boy from school that she doesn't seem to know very well. He does nothing. Mostly stand around watching her do stuff.After the movie ended I had SO many questions. Where did they go? Another planet? Another Universe? Another time? How did they get there? Something to do with frequencies apparently. Where did the women come from? The same universe her father was in? Apparently the women somehow help people
column6: I guess. Kinda. Why did the women wait so long to help her?There's lots of visual candy and little kids will probably like that. But there's lots of nothing as well. Also lots of vague warnings and such and confusing things that are never explained and nobody seems to care. They say things like ""where are we?"" ""Were on such and such. ""OK"". No
column7: it's not OK. Where is that? Is it a planet? Is it in our galaxy? Universe? We'll never know.The performances are pretty bland. Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon seem to be going a bit overboard to make up for everyone else just standing around talking.It was hard to really care about these characters. The movie wanted you to care about them without really giving you a reason to.I haven't read the books
column8: so hopefully they explain things better than this movie did and if you've read them it makes more sense.Oh. And one last thing. I'm sick and tired of people making up definitions of what a tesseract is. No
column9: a tesseract is not whatever they said it was in this movie.";7 August 2019
